metadata.title: Comparison between sustainable cryogenic techniques and nano-MQL cooling mode in turning of nickel-based alloy

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Journal of Cleaner Production
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ jc lepro
Comparison between sustainable cryogenic techniques and nano-MQL cooling mode in turning of nickel-based alloy
Chetan a, *, S. Ghosh b, P.V. Rao b
a Department of Mechanical Engineering, PEC (Deemed to be University), Sector 12, Chandigarh, India b Department of Mechanical Engineering, IIT Delhi, Hauz Khas, New Delhi, India
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 23 October 2018 Received in revised form 15 May 2019 Accepted 17 May 2019 Available online 27 May 2019
Keywords: Cryogenic cooling Cryogenic treatment MQL Nickel-based alloy Sustainable machining
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: chetan.harry@gmail.com (Chetan)
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.05.196 0959-6526/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Mineral based metal working fluids used in machining, results in environmental pollution and occupational health hazards for the operators. Consequently it is necessary to evolve out machining techniques which are environment friendly. In the present work, techniques such as cryogenic cooling and cryogenic treatment have been compared with Al2O3 nanoparticles based MQL cooling method (nMQL) in turning of the nickel based Nimonic 90 alloy. The machining of nickel based alloy has been carried out using the AlTiN coated tungsten carbide inserts of different nose radii. The effects of these cutting environments have been studied by comparing the tool wear, cutting forces, work surface defects, surface finish, and chip underside surfaces. The application of liquid nitrogen as a cooling medium significantly reduced the tool flank wear of the 0.2mm nose radius insert by 38% as compared to nMQL technique. The SEM investigation of rake face revealed that the cryogenic cooling technique has also prevented the groove formation and peeling of the coating. The effective cushioning effect of liquid nitrogen as coolant improved the surface finish as compared to other techniques. The cryogenic cooling reduced the defects such as material side flow, material redeposition and micro cavities over the machined surface. Overall the cryogenic cooling environment has been found to be the best mode for the machining of the Nimonic 90 alloy.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, the concept of sustainability in metal cutting domain has become of a great interest for the researchers due to the strict rules and regulations imposed by the governmental agencies (Chetan et al., 2015). Sustainability deals with the production of finished goods by reducing the amount of energy utilization, contaminations, emissions, health risks, and natural resources (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017). According to Diaz et al. (2010) sustainability in machining can be achieved by reducing the power consumption, waste generation and environmental impacts. In machining, cutting fluid is one such component which significantly affects the sustainability of the overall process (Debnath et al., 2014).
Approximately 100 years ago, F W Taylor discovered that the application of coolant can substantially enhance the productivity by reducing the cutting temperature (Araújo Junior et al., 2017). At present around 85% of cutting fluid used around the world are mineral based metal cutting fluids (MWFs) (Chetan et al., 2015;
.
Debnath et al., 2014). However, the use of MWFs during machining is creating many socio-economic and environmental related issues (Singh et al., 2019). The equipment required for the delivery of cutting fluid consumes a lot of energy. Further, huge sum of money is also required for the regular operation and maintenance of the cutting fluid equipment. The post treatment of the cutting fluids for the disposal purpose also requires a lot of investment. According to previous researchers the cost related to the use of MWFs for difficult to machine materials can reach up to 17e30% of the overall machining cost (Pusavec et al., 2010). Half of the cost associated with the cutting fluids goes into disposal and chemical treatment. The presence of microorganisms, biocides, and toxic metal particles in the usedMWFs can cause skin and respiration problems amongst the workers (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017). Approximately around 80% occupational skin diseases have been caused by conventional MWFs throughout the world (Lawal et al., 2012). In addition to this, the formaldehyde present within the mineral based cutting fluids also increases the risk of skin cancer. The chemical additives such as chlorine and sulfur in MWFs used for controlling the friction are considered very dangerous for human health and eco-system. These chemical additives make the machining process uneconomic by increasing the disposal cost of MWFs by 7 times (Shokrani
et al., 2012). Along with lung disease the aerosols of cutting fluids can also cause stomach, pancreas, and esophagus cancer. Keeping in view all the negative aspects, it is now becoming essential to make the machining more sustainable by limiting the usage of cutting fluid during the cutting process.
The most popular way to approach towards the unsustainable fluid free cutting is the dry machining. This technique limits the machining cost and environmental hazard caused by the metal working fluids (Weinert et al., 2004). However, for the difficult to machinematerials such as nickel based alloys, machining under dry mode is considered to be a very challenging task (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017).
High temperature produced during machining under dry mode can reduce the strength of cutting insert by causing plastic deformation (Ezilarasan et al., 2013). High mechanical and thermal loading associated with dry machining result in the surface defects such as grooves formation, metal debris deposition, micro fracture, and smearing of material (Mishra et al., 2019; Sharman et al., 2004). The absence of cutting fluids can also reduce tool life, generate poor surface finish, and results in low production rate. For the nickel based super alloys, themachining under drymode leads to built-up edge (BUE) and built-up layer (BUL) formation over rake face (Devillez et al., 2007).
Therefore, it is necessary to explore the other emerging techniques which can make the dry machining more efficient and sustainable. Cryogenic treatment is one such emerging technique which has been successfully implemented to improve the hardness, wear resistance and strength of the cutting inserts by cooling them below 0 C for several hours (Chetan et al., 2017). Recently, Ӧzbek et al. (2014) applied the deep cryogenic treatment at 145 C over the tungsten carbide inserts for the machining of AISI 316 stainless steel. The cryogenic processing improved the tool flank wear by 29% at the cutting speed 100m/min under dry condition. At the same cutting speed, the improvement in notch wear was found to be 69%. The precipitation of eta (h) particles and the improvement in thermal conductivity were considered as the reasons for the improved wear behaviour of the cutting insert after cryogenic processing. In another work, Gill et al. (2011b) conducted cryogenic treatment of coated carbide inserts at 110 C for 4 h. The subzero treatment resulted in the prevention of notch formation, chipping and plastic deformation of cutting thereby enhancing the tool life by 25.53% during the dry machining of C65 hot rolled steel. Likewise, the cryogenically treated tungsten carbide inserts at 176 C was employed for the machining of AISI 1040 steel (Reddy et al., 2009). As compared to untreated inserts the use of cryogenically treated inserts under dry mode provided improved results in terms of reduced surface finish (20%), lesser cutting force (11%) and improved tool life (27%).
The other popular technique which can be employed to reduce the usage of cutting fluid during machining is called as minimum quantity lubrication (MQL) (Chetan et al., 2018). According to Weinert et al. (2004) MQL can also be considered as the central element in dry machining strategy. Due to the use of low fluid flow rate, this technique is also known as near dry machining (NDM) (Boswell et al., 2017). In order to impart sustainability during machining process many researchers have used biodegradable vegetable oils under MQL mode (Chetan et al., 2015). However, due to low thermal conductivity and poor miscibility of vegetable oils, researchers are now trying their hands on more advanced fluids for MQL application such as Nanofluids (NFs) (Chetan et al., 2016). Apart from high thermal conductivity, nanofluids also offer the advantage of friction reduction through rolling mechanism (Sinha
et al., 2017). Recently, Najiha et al. (2016) conducted machining of aluminum AA6061-T6 alloy using different volume fractions of nano TiO2 in de-ionized water. After machining it has been found that the use of NFs successfully reduced the edge chipping and edge fracture. In another work, the machining of AISI 1040 steel was conducted using nano MoS2 dispersed in different vegetable oils (Padmini et al., 2016). As compared to dry machining the nano MoS2 enhanced coolant under MQLmode reduced the cutting force and temperature by 37% and 21% respectively. The effect of nanofluids has also been explored in grinding process. The grinding of Ti6Al4V was conducted using water based Al2O3 and CuO nanofluids under MQL mode (Setti et al., 2015). As compared to dry mode, the use of Al2O3 nanofluids significantly reduced the apparent coefficient of friction due to a tribo-film formation over the titanium work piece.
Many researchers have also preferred the use of liquid nitrogen (LN2) because it leaves no harmful residue after its usage during machining (Reddy and Ghosh, 2016). LN2 also possesses an excellent cooling capacity to improve the tool life during the machining of difficult to machine materials (Shokrani et al., 2012). Due to the reduction in abrasion and attrition mechanisms upon using the LN2 during machining of Ti alloy, the flank wear got significantly reduced by 31% as compared to conventional flood machining (Dhananchezian and Kumar, 2011). In another work on machining of Ti alloy, the use of liquid nitrogen restricted the formation of BUE over the rake face of the cutting insert (Bordin et al., 2015). Along with this, the use of LN2 also prevented the formation of crater and improved the surface integrity of the machined work piece as compared to dry machining.
It is clear from the literature review that all the three techniques have the potential to improve the effectiveness of machining without using the unsustainable MWFs. These techniques can successfully be used for the machining of difficult to machine materials. Therefore, all the three techniques have been used for the machining of nickel based Nimonic 90 alloy for a comparative analysis. The effect of different cutting speeds and feed rates under all the three conditions have also been studied during the turning process. Many authors have also considered tool nose radius as an important parameter which can significantly influence the cutting forces and surface integrity during the machining (Chou and Song, 2004; Sharman et al., 2015). Therefore, the effect of variation in cutting insert nose radius has also been investigated in this research work.

sections.heading: 2. Cutting conditions
sections.text:
Cryogenic treatment (CT): The cryogenic treatment was conducted using the Primero Enserve make cryogenic processor CP220LH. In this study, the carbide inserts were subjected to the deep cryogenic treatment at 196 C for 12 h followed by the tempering cycle of 2 h.
Nanofluid based MQL (nMQL): In this study, Al2O3 nanoparticles have been mixed in water with the help of magnetic stirrer by providing a rotation of 1000 rpm. The volumetric concentration of 0.5% of Al2O3 inwater has been selected. The prepared nanofluid was employed at the cutting zone with the help of an indigenous MQL system (flow rate of 125ml/h and pressure of 4 bar).
Stability of nanofluid has been examined by measuring the zeta potential. Zetasizer by Malvern Instruments Ltd, UK has been used for quantifying the zeta potential of prepared nanofluid. This instrument works on the principle of dynamic light scattering (DLS). Zeta potential for the prepared alumina nanofluid has been found to be 22.8mv. Generally, nanofluids are considered to be stable if their zeta potential is near ±30mv. The stability of nanoparticles in
fluid has been further improved by addition of small amount of SDS surfactant in the prepared fluid.
Thermal conductivity of nanofluid has also beenmeasured using KD2 Pro thermal conductivity analyzer (Decagon Devices Inc. USA). This apparatus works on the principle of transient hot wire technique. This device is consisting of a 60mm long and 1.3mm diameter probe, which incorporates a heating element and a thermo-resistor. The probe is connected to a microprocessor unit for the measurement purpose. The thermal conductivity value of 0.6W/mK for alumina nanofluid has been found to be 10% greater than the thermal conductivity of base fluid without nanoparticles. The combined effect of Brownian motion, liquid layering and aggregation of NPs are the major reasons for such increase in the thermal conductivity of the nanofluids.
Cryogenic cooling (CC): Cryofab™ made Dewar has been used to store the liquid nitrogen to be supplied to the cutting zone. The flow of LN2 has been directed over the tool rake with the help of a nozzle.
The schematic and set ups for cryogenic cooling, MQL and cryogenic treatment techniques are given in Fig. 1.
Cutting parameter: All the cutting experiments have been carried out on the Leadwell T6 CNC turning center. Five cutting
speeds (20, 40, 60, 80 and 100m/min), five feed rates (0.04, 0.08, 0.12, 0.16, 0.2 mm/rev), five nose radii (0.2, 0.4, 0.8, 1.2 and 1.6mm) and constant depth of cut of 0.5mm have used for the machining. A total number of 18 experiments for each environment have been performed as per the central composite design (CCD) of response surface methodology. Every experiment has been repeated three times and the readings for each trial recorded separately.

sections.heading: 3.1. Comparative analysis of cutting forces
sections.text:
Minitab 17 software has been used to plot the main effect of speed, feed and nose radius over the main cutting force in different cutting environments. The P-value obtained from the statistical analysis for the feed rate was found to be 0.001 in all the cutting conditions. This shows the effectiveness of feed rate over other machining parameters. From Fig. 2 it can be seen that the feed rate is the most effective parameter for the increase in the main cutting force followed by the cutting speed and the nose radius. Fig. 3a shows the percentage contribution graph of different cutting parameters under different cutting environments for the main cutting
g, MQL and Cryogenic treatment techniques.
force obtained from the analysis of variance (ANOVA). From this figure it can also be concluded that the contribution of feed in increasing the main cutting force is very high as compared to speed and nose radius. This is mainly because the increase in feed rate increases the material removal rate during the machining. This leads to an increase in thermo-mechanical fatigue due to the generation of high normal and shear stresses over the tool rake face and hence results in higher cutting forces (Cantero et al., 2013). The other possible reason for the increase in cutting force is the increase in contact length with the feed rate. From the previous research work on machining of Nimonic 90, it was found that the increase in feed rate from 0.08 mm/rev to 0.16 mm/rev increased the overall contact length by 30e60% (Chetan et al., 2017). This not only leads to more BUE formation but also increases the coefficient of friction over the tool rake face and hence increases the overall cutting force.
Further Fig. 3b shows percentage contribution of various parameters for the thrust force. It is clear from this graph that the nose radius is the most dominant parameter followed by feed rate. The contribution of cutting speed is negligible as compared to other
Fig. 4. Main effect plot of different (a) nose radii, (b)
parameters. Due to the high contribution of nose radius the increase in the thrust force is also significantly high as shown in Fig. 4a.
From Fig. 4c it can be seen that the increase in feed from 0.04 mm/rev to 0.2 mm/rev resulted in minor increase in the thrust force. The cutting speed has been found to be the least significant which caused almost no change in the thrust force.
For the same depth of cut the increase in nose radius decreases the cutting edge angle according to the following formula (Nath et al., 2009).
Kr ¼ cos 1 rn ap
rn
where, Kr is the cutting edge angle rn is the nose radius, ap is the depth of cut.
The decrease in cutting edge angle changes the direction of the resultant force acting over the rake face in a clockwise direction as suggested by Chen (2000). As a result of this, the thrust force
cutting speed, and (c) feed rates on thrust force.

increases significantly with the increase in tool nose radius. On the other hand, the increase in the cutting edge angle with a small nose radius resulted in significantly less thrust force.
Apart from the cutting parameters, the cutting environments have also influenced the mean cutting forces. The mean main cutting force was found to be 278.4 N with cryogenically treated inserts at 20m/min of cutting speed. For the same cutting speed, the use of alumina nanoparticles based nMQL and liquid nitrogen under cryogenic cooling condition reduced the cutting force to 240.2 N and 269.5 N respectively. Similarly, at the higher cutting speed of 80m/min, the use of nMQL and LN2 reduced the cutting force by 16.25% and 4.73% as compared to cutting with cryogenically treated inserts under dry mode. It has been discussed by Setti et al. (2014), that the use of Al2O3 nanofluid results in the formation of a tribofilm. The tribofilm might have reduced the friction between the tool rake face and chip and hence resulted in significant reduction in cutting force.

sections.heading: 3.2. Tool wear on flank face
sections.text:
Tool wear on flank face obtained for all the cutting environments will be discussed in this section. Optical microscopy and SEM analysis have been carried out to measure the tool wear in microns.
Fig. 5a shows the overall effect of different nose radii over the flank wear after the machining under different cutting environments. It can be seen from this figure that the use of 0.2mm nose radius insert yielded the highest amount of flank wear for all the cutting conditions. The increase in nose radius from 0.2mm to 1.6mm has significantly reduced the tool wear. Recently, Zhao et al. (2017) have also discussed the effect of cutting edge radius during the machining of AISI 52100 steel. They have also observed that the higher edge radius insert helped in reduction of flank wear as compared to lower edge radius insert.
The variation in tool wear with nose radii at 60m/min of cutting speed, and 0.12 mm/rev of feed can also be depicted from the SEM micrographs as shown in Fig. 6. It is clear from themicrographs that as compared to large nose radius insert, the use of small nose radius insert provided the highest amount of tool wear. In this context, the use of 0.2mm cryogenically processed insert yielded the flankwear of 180 mm. The use of alumina nanofluids under MQL mode providedmarginal advantage over cryogenically treated insert in terms of tool flank wear. The flank wear with nMQL condition has been found to be 176 mm. The highest decrease in the flank wear while using 0.2mm nose radius insert has been observed with cryogenic cooling condition. The use of LN2 has reduced the flank wear by approximately 38% as compared to nMQL and treated insert condition.
The use of 1.6mmnose radius cryogenically treated insert under similar parametric conditions, reduced the flank wear approximately by 50% as compared to 0.2mm nose radius. A similar type of reduction in flankwearwas also observed for cryogenic cooling and nMQL conditions with 1.6mm insert in comparison to 0.2mm insert. As compared to the small nose radius insert, the stress concentration was less in case of large nose radius insert due to an increase in the shear area (Xiao et al., 2003). It is due to this reason that the large tool nose radius was able to prevent the plastic deformation of the tool during the cutting. However, the high concentration of stress in small nose radius insert resulted in early tool wear due to fracture especially with cryogenically processed inserts and nMQL condition.
The same type of phenomenon has been also observed in terms of tool wear when two different nose radii inserts have been employed for machining at 80m/min of cutting speed, and 0.16 mm/rev of feed under different cutting environments as shown in Fig. 7. Here, the dry cutting environment for the cryogenically
treated inserts provided excessively high tool flank wear as compared to cryogenic cooling and nMQL conditions with 0.4mm nose radius. The mainmechanism of tool wear under all the cutting environments has been the notch formation over the flank face. The excessive strain rate (>106 s 1) caused by the combination of high speed (80m/min) and high feed (0.16mm/rev) for the machining of nickel-based Nimonic 90 alloy generated excessive flow stresses over the cutting inserts (Srinivasa and Prasad, 1995). Due to the high sharpness of the low nose radius inserts, it was easier for the
high concentrated flow stresses to cause the plastic deformation of 0.4mm nose radius cutting inserts through notch formation.
Here also the use of 1.2mm nose radius insert significantly suppressed the tool flank wear in comparison to low nose radius insert for the same speed and feed condition. The large nose radius provided the necessary strength to the cutting insert to withstand the flow stresses thereby causing the low tool wear.
Apart from low tool nose radius, the use of high cutting speed has significantly increased the flank wear for nMQL and
cryogenically processed insert. The SEMmicrographs at high speed of 100m/min are provided in Fig. 8. It can be seen from the micrographs that the high-speed condition has resulted in excessive wear for the cryogenically treated insert. The cryogenic treatment is known for imparting higher hardness, toughness, wear resistance of the cutting inserts (Gill et al., 2011a; SreeramaReddy et al., 2009). Despite this, the cryogenically treated insert was unable to withstand the higher temperature and stresses generated during the high speed machining of Nimonic 90.
The use of alumina-based nanoparticles under nMQL condition was also unable to protect the cutting insert from catastrophic flank wear and BUE formation. The machining at high cutting speed has resulted in the adhesion of chip material in the form of BUE. Actually, at high cutting speed, the temperature at the cutting zone become very high. The fluid reaching in the form of mist evaporates quickly at such a high temperature and form a vapor layer between the chip and the tool rake surface. This phenomenon of vapor layer formation is known as Leidenfrost effect. The formation of such layer reduces the heat transfer rate at the cutting zone which further results in excessive tool wear and adhesion over the cutting insert (Behera et al., 2017a).
Unlike the other two techniques, the use of cryogenic cooling significantly reduced the tool flank wear at 100m/min of cutting speed. The low tool wear in cryogenic cooling is due to the high value of the coefficient of heat transfer (CHT). In an experimental work conducted by Dreister (2003), the CHT for cryogenic LN2 was found to be 1700e6500 W/m2K. Due to high CHT, the LN2 has a higher capacity of heat evacuation from the cutting zone as compared to other cutting fluids. This might have played an important role in significantly reducing the tool flank wear during cryogenic machining of Nimonic 90. However, as per Jiang et al. (2016) the CHT for MQL and dry machining was found to be 678W/m2K and 122W/m2K respectively. The lower value of CHT in both cases as compared to cryogenic cooling has resulted in extremely high tool wear at high cutting speed.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of cutting environments on rake surface
sections.text:
Effect of the cutting environments on the rake face during machining has been discussed in this section. Fig. 9 shows the SEM micrographs of different zones of rake face at the lower cutting speed of 20m/min. Due to the low cutting speed, the continuous flow of chip over rake face was not able to do any severe damage to the rake face in all three cutting environments. At lower magnification, only some chip debris has been observed over the rake face of cutting insert used under nMQL mode. Similarly, at lower magnification, only the adhesion near the cutting edge has been observed for the cryogenically treated inserts.
The close investigation of rake face at sliding and sticking zone has been carried out by increasing the magnification of SEM
micrographs. The sliding zone surface of the cryogenic cooling condition has been found to be smooth as compared to other conditions. However, the continuous sliding of chip peeled off the coating from the rake face for the cryogenic cooling condition. For the same machining parameters, the application of nMQL resulted in the formation of grooves on the sliding zone. In the previous research work, it has been explained that the grooves formation over the rake face is the cause of abrasive action caused by the alumina nanoparticles during nMQL condition (Chetan et al., 2016). Unlike cryogenic cooling and nMQL conditions, the absence of lubrication for the cryogenically treated insert has resulted in coating damage at the end of the sliding zone and resulted in severe abrasion groove formation.
Further, negligible chipping of the cutting edge of the insert in sticking zone has been found under cryogenic cooling condition. The formation of the gaseous cushion by LN2 at the sticking zone as suggested by Hong et al. (2001) could be the possible reason for such damaged free cutting edge. It is due to the same reason that the LN2 prevented the adhesion of the chip fragments over the sticking zone as compared to the other conditions.
The effect of machining Nimonic 90 on the rake face has also been realized at the high cutting speed of 80m/min as shown in Fig. 10. It can be seen from the images of the sliding zone that the absence of cutting fluid during the machining with the cryogenically treated inserts resulted in excessive coating damage and grooves formation over the rake face. Undoubtedly, the high friction experienced by the rake face under dry mode might be the reason for high rake face wear. At the same cutting speed, the use of nMQL has been not able to stop the coating peeling in the sliding zone over rake face. The intense heat produced at 80m/min for the machining of nickel-based alloy evaporated the MQL fluid quickly, thereby not allowing the nanoparticles to perform the rolling action in the cutting zone. This possibly has increased the rubbing at the cutting zone which further resulted in the coating peeling off. At the sticking zone, the severe loading condition resulted in excessive chipping of the cutting edge of the cryogenically treated insert. The length of the cutting zone has been found to be 174.08 mm for this condition. Similarly, the cutting at high speed has resulted in the deformation of the cutting edge in the sticking zone for the nMQL condition. The length of the sticking zone for the nMQL condition has also been found to be relatively high. Unlike dry (cryogenically treated inserts) and nMQL conditions, the application of LN2 has prevented chipping and deformation of the cutting edge of the sticking zone. The excellent cooling capacity of cryogenic coolant has reduced the sticking zone length by approximately 60% as compared to the other cutting environments.
Elemental analysis (EDX) at the sticking and sliding zones of the cutting inserts used for machining at 80m/min has been carried out and the results obtained are as shown in Fig. 11.
Theweight percentage of different elements found in the sliding
00m/min and 0.12 mm/rev under different cutting environments.
and sticking zones after the EDX analysis is given in Fig. 12. Through the elemental analysis, it has been found that the percentage of W (39.88%) at the sliding zone under nMQL mode has been found to considerably high as compared to the other two conditions. The higher percentage of tungsten is the result of the peeling of coating in case of nMQL mode as discussed earlier.
In case of cryogenically treated inserts, significant amount of Ni (39.2%), Cr (14.73%) and Co (14.36%) have been detected in the sliding zone. This possibly have occurred due to the high temperature experienced by the treated insert under dry machining. The high temperature possibly has resulted in the built-up layer formation over the rake surface thereby, increasing the percentage of work piece elements over the sliding zone (G omez-Parra et al., 2013). Surprisingly, the continuous flow of chip also resulted in
the increase of work piece elements (Ni, Cr and Co) over the sliding zone under cryogenic condition. High chemical affinity of work piece elements could be responsible for their presence in the sliding zone. This can also be confirmed by the line scan elemental analysis of tool rake face as shown in Fig. 13. The increase in the percentage of Ni, Cr and Co which are possibly obtained from the work piece at the sliding zone under all the cutting environments indicates about the strong affinity of these elements with the tool material.
The elemental analysis has also been performed at the sticking zone for all the conditions. The presence of high amount of tungsten in case of cryogenically treated insert indicates the loss of the coating due to the chipping as shown earlier in the SEM micrographs. Whereas, the alumina based nanofluid resulted in an
sliding and sticking zones over the rake face.
increase in weight percentage of Al (13.23%) in case of nMQL as compared to the other conditions.
3.4. Surface finish
The variations in surface roughness (Ra) with varying nose radius, cutting speed and feed rate are shown in Fig. 14. It is clear from Fig. 14a that the increase in nose radius from 0.2mm to 1.6mm during the machining resulted in the reduction of surface roughness value for all the cutting environments. The use of 0.2mm, nose radius tool has yielded the high surface roughness value of 1.24 mm, 1.03 mm, and 0.62 mm with cryogenically treated inserts, cryogenic cooling, and, nMQL respectively. Whereas, the
use of 1.6mm radius inserts reduced the surface roughness to 0.25 mm, 0.52 mm, and 0.26 mm with cryogenically treated inserts, cryogenic cooling, and nMQL environments respectively. Dilbag and Rao (2008) also reported same behaviour regarding the variation of surface roughness with nose radius of cutting inserts during the machining of AISI52100 steel. According to a mathematical relation, the surface roughness obtained during machining is inversely proportional to the nose radius of cutting insert (Boothroyd, 1988). Therefore, according to this relation the use of large nose radius has resulted in a reduction of surface roughness with all the cutting environments. It has also been seen in the previous section on tool wear, that the use of large nose radius during turning of Nimonic 90 resulted in less tool wear as
se radii, (b) cutting speeds, and (c) feed rates.
compared to small nose radius insert. Since, the increase in tool wear also increases the surface roughness of the work surface, therefore, the low tool wear exhibited by large tool nose radius insert further improved the surface finish under all the cutting environments.
Fig. 14b shows the variation of surface roughness with cutting speed. Generally, it is assumed that the surface roughness decreases with the increase in cutting speed. However, during the machining of Nimonic 90, the increase in cutting speed has led to increase in the surface roughness for all the cutting environments. For example, the machining at 20m/min has provided the mean surface roughness value of 0.27 mm, 0.35 mm, and 0.42 mm for cryogenic cooling, cryogenically treated insert and nMQL conditions respectively. Increase of the cutting speed to 100m/min has increased the Ra value to 0.76 mm, 0.98 mm, and 0.56 mm under cryogenic cooling, cryogenically treated and nMQL conditions respectively. The cutting edge fracture and high flank wear under dry mode have significantly increased the Ra when cryogenically treated insert has bee used for the machining at such high speed.
The increase in feed rate has also increased the surface roughness during machining of Nimonic 90 alloy as shown in Fig. 14c. As compared to 0.04 mm/rev the increase of feed to 0.2 mm/rev has significantly increased the surface roughness for all the cutting conditions. The maximum increase in the surface roughness value has been observed for the nMQL condition. The combination of
increased tool wear together with the abrasion causing tendency of the alumina NPs possibly have increased the Ra value (Chetan et al., 2016). On the other hand, the effective lubrication and cushioning effect of LN2 at the cutting zone have resulted in substantial reduction in surface roughness.

sections.heading: 3.5. Work surface defects
sections.text:
The high mechanical and thermal loads during the machining of nickel-based alloy can result in the formation of certain undesirable features over the machined surface which are known as surface defects (Thakur and Gangopadhyay, 2016). The effect of cutting environments and cutting insert nose radius on the machined surfaces during machining at 60m/min of cutting speed has been studied with the help of SEM micrographs as shown in Fig. 15. For the lower nose radius of 0.2mm the material side flow and feed marks are the common surface defects detected for all the cutting environments. The material side flow is also termed as folded laps (Thakur and Gangopadhyay, 2016). The early damage of tool cutting edge for the lower nose radius insert due to less strength could be the possible reason for such surface anomalies. Surprisingly, the use of cryogenic coolant has also been not able to stop the formation of such folded laps during machining with 0.2mm radius insert. The early breakage of tool cutting edge has not allowed the proper lubrication film formation at the cutting zone. This could be
m/min and 0.12 mm/rev under different cutting environments.
considered as the possible reason for such defects in LN2 condition. For the same cutting speed the use of 0.8mm nose radius insert significantly reduced the surface defects for the cryogenic cooling and nMQL conditions. For the cryogenic condition, only small debris has been observed over the machined surface. The machining with alumina nanofluid under MQL mode resulted in feed marks and micro particles deposition over the machined surface. The micro particles deposition over the surface is the result of adhesion of chip fragments from the chip over the machined surface. The same cutting condition resulted in excessive material redeposition over the machined surface for the cryogenically treated inserts. Recently, Behera et al. (2017a) suggested that the high temperature generated during dry machining of nickel-based alloy is the reason for the material redeposition. Since the machining of Nimonic 90 with cryogenically treated inserts has been carried out under dry cutting environment, therefore, the high temperature generated may be considered as the primary reason for such adherence of material over the machined surface.
For the machining with 1.6mm nose radius insert at 60m/min of cutting, the machined surface was found to be free from surface anomalies as seen with lower tool nose radius insert. The machining under cryogenic coolant resulted in a very smooth
Fig. 16. 3D topographic images of machined surface after mac
surface with this high nose radius insert. On the other hand, excessive micro cavities have been observed when Nimonic 90 was machined with cryo processed insert. The lack of effective lubrication during machining of treated inserts may have resulted in the tearing of machined surface in the form of micro cavities. Themicro cavities have also been seen in the nMQL condition during machining. However, the tribofilm formation by the Al2O3 might have resulted in reduction of the number of micro cavities as compared to machining with cryogenically treated insert.
For further analysis of the machined surfaces, the 3D topographic images have been taken with the help of stereozoom microscope as shown in Fig. 16. The analysis of the images has been carried out with the help of Confomap software. From the topographic analysis, it can be seen that the surface machined with cryogenically treated insert appear to be very rough and irregular. It consists of several surface defects such as deep grooves, material redeposition, and, thick feed marks.
The deep grooves on the surface are caused by the dragging of deposited material over the machined surface during the course of machining. The presence of significant amount of redeposited material of approximately 1 mm height in Fig. 16a also supports the deep groove formation under dry condition. The high friction due
hining at 60m/min under different cutting environments.
to the absence of lubrication in this condition also resulted in thick feed marks formation over the machined surface. On the other hand, the use of nMQL and cryogenic cooling condition resulted in very smooth surface free from surface irregularities. The reduction in tool wear and thermal distortion in the cryogenic cooling condition could be the possible reason for the smooth feed marks over the machined surface (Behera et al., 2017a). For the nMQL condition, the friction reduction due to the rolling action of Al2O3 nanoparticles possibly has resulted in the formation of such thin feed marks (Behera et al., 2017b).

sections.heading: 3.6. Chip underside surface analysis
sections.text: The analysis of chip underside surface has been carried out at 80m/min of cutting speed for the environments as shown in Fig. 17. Compared to cryogenic cooling condition, excessive chip side flow has been observed for the nMQL and cryogenically treated condtion. The inability of nanofluid to penetrate at this high speed machining condition probably the cause of chip side flow in case of nMQL condition. For the machining with treated inserts under dry condition, the excessive rise in machining zone temperature at 80m/min may have been the reason for the plastic side flow of the chip at the edge. The generation of high stresses during high speed machining of nickel-based alloy also resulted in the crack formation within the chips under nMQL and cryogenically treated condition. Further, adhesion of micro particle has also been observed when the Nimonic is machined with treated inserts under dry mode. Dragging of micro particles over the machined surface during the machining may be the possible reason for the deep groove formation over the surface as shown in previous section. The rolling of these particles between the chip and the rake face increases the frictional work at the cutting zone which in turn increases the rake face wear, cutting temperature, surface defects and cutting forces during the machining. Several small chip fragments have also been observed attached to the underside surface of chip produced in nMQL condition. The adhesion of these fragments has resulted in the formation of very fine friction tracks. The chip underside surface for the cryogenic cooling condition has been found to be relatively smooth as compared to the other two conditions.

sections.heading: 3.7. Conclusions
sections.text:
Upon conducting the machining of Nimonic 90 under different cutting environments the following conclusion can be drawn:
Feed rate has been found to be the most effective parameter in increasing the main cutting force. For the high cutting speed of 80m/min, the use of alumina nanofluids under MQL mode reduced the main cutting force by 16%. The use of high tool nose radius significantly reduced the wear over the flank face for all the cutting environments. The high cooling capacity of liquid nitrogen prevented the fracture and notch formation at the high cutting speed of 100m/ min. The use of cryogenic coolant significantly improved the cutting edge condition by reducing the length of sticking zone during the machining. The use of 0.2mm nose radius insert produced many surface defects even with cryogenic cooling condition. The reduction in the friction at the cutting zone by cryogenic coolant resulted in the formation of smooth chip underside surface.
It has been found that the performance of large nose radius inserts is better as compared to the small nose radius inserts. Further, the cryogenic cooling environment has been found to be the best environment followed by nMQL during the machining of Nimonic 90. The cryogenically treated inserts (Dry condition) under performed in terms of tool wear especially at high cutting speed conditions.

referenceMentions.context: In recent years, the concept of sustainability in metal cutting domain has become of a great interest for the researchers due to the strict rules and regulations imposed by the governmental agencies (Chetan et al., 2015).
Sustainability deals with the production of finished goods by reducing the amount of energy utilization, contaminations, emissions, health risks, and natural resources (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017).
In machining, cutting fluid is one such component which significantly affects the sustainability of the overall process (Debnath et al., 2014).
However, the use of MWFs during machining is creating many socio-economic and environmental related issues (Singh et al., 2019).
According to previous researchers the cost related to the use of MWFs for difficult to machine materials can reach up to 17e30% of the overall machining cost (Pusavec et al., 2010).
The presence of microorganisms, biocides, and toxic metal particles in the usedMWFs can cause skin and respiration problems amongst the workers (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017).
Approximately around 80% occupational skin diseases have been caused by conventional MWFs throughout the world (Lawal et al., 2012).
This technique limits the machining cost and environmental hazard caused by the metal working fluids (Weinert et al., 2004).
However, for the difficult to machinematerials such as nickel based alloys, machining under dry mode is considered to be a very challenging task (Goindi and Sarkar, 2017).
High temperature produced during machining under dry mode can reduce the strength of cutting insert by causing plastic deformation (Ezilarasan et al., 2013).

High mechanical and thermal loading associated with dry machining result in the surface defects such as grooves formation, metal debris deposition, micro fracture, and smearing of material (Mishra et al., 2019; Sharman et al., 2004).

High mechanical and thermal loading associated with dry machining result in the surface defects such as grooves formation, metal debris deposition, micro fracture, and smearing of material (Mishra et al., 2019; Sharman et al., 2004).
For the nickel based super alloys, themachining under drymode leads to built-up edge (BUE) and built-up layer (BUL) formation over rake face (Devillez et al., 2007).

Cryogenic treatment is one such emerging technique which has been successfully implemented to improve the hardness, wear resistance and strength of the cutting inserts by cooling them below 0 C for several hours (Chetan et al., 2017).
Likewise, the cryogenically treated tungsten carbide inserts at 176 C was employed for the machining of AISI 1040 steel (Reddy et al., 2009).
The other popular technique which can be employed to reduce the usage of cutting fluid during machining is called as minimum quantity lubrication (MQL) (Chetan et al., 2018).
Due to the use of low fluid flow rate, this technique is also known as near dry machining (NDM) (Boswell et al., 2017).
In order to impart sustainability during machining process many researchers have used biodegradable vegetable oils under MQL mode (Chetan et al., 2015).

However, due to low thermal conductivity and poor miscibility of vegetable oils, researchers are now trying their hands on more advanced fluids for MQL application such as Nanofluids (NFs) (Chetan et al., 2016).
Apart from high thermal conductivity, nanofluids also offer the advantage of friction reduction through rolling mechanism (Sinha et al., 2017).
In another work, the machining of AISI 1040 steel was conducted using nano MoS2 dispersed in different vegetable oils (Padmini et al., 2016).
The grinding of Ti6Al4V was conducted using water based Al2O3 and CuO nanofluids under MQL mode (Setti et al., 2015).
Many researchers have also preferred the use of liquid nitrogen (LN2) because it leaves no harmful residue after its usage during machining (Reddy and Ghosh, 2016).
LN2 also possesses an excellent cooling capacity to improve the tool life during the machining of difficult to machine materials (Shokrani et al., 2012).

Due to the reduction in abrasion and attrition mechanisms upon using the LN2 during machining of Ti alloy, the flank wear got significantly reduced by 31% as compared to conventional flood machining (Dhananchezian and Kumar, 2011).
In another work on machining of Ti alloy, the use of liquid nitrogen restricted the formation of BUE over the rake face of the cutting insert (Bordin et al., 2015).

Many authors have also considered tool nose radius as an important parameter which can significantly influence the cutting forces and surface integrity during the machining (Chou and Song, 2004; Sharman et al., 2015).

Many authors have also considered tool nose radius as an important parameter which can significantly influence the cutting forces and surface integrity during the machining (Chou and Song, 2004; Sharman et al., 2015).
For the same depth of cut the increase in nose radius decreases the cutting edge angle according to the following formula (Nath et al., 2009).
As compared to the small nose radius insert, the stress concentration was less in case of large nose radius insert due to an increase in the shear area (Xiao et al., 2003).
The cryogenic treatment is known for imparting higher hardness, toughness, wear resistance of the cutting inserts (Gill et al., 2011a; SreeramaReddy et al., 2009).

In the previous research work, it has been explained that the grooves formation over the rake face is the cause of abrasive action caused by the alumina nanoparticles during nMQL condition (Chetan et al., 2016).
According to a mathematical relation, the surface roughness obtained during machining is inversely proportional to the nose radius of cutting insert (Boothroyd, 1988).

SEM micrographs of machined surface after machining at 60 increased tool wear together with the abrasion causing tendency of the alumina NPs possibly have increased the Ra value (Chetan et al., 2016).

The high mechanical and thermal loads during the machining of nickel-based alloy can result in the formation of certain undesirable features over the machined surface which are known as surface defects (Thakur and Gangopadhyay, 2016).
The material side flow is also termed as folded laps (Thakur and Gangopadhyay, 2016).

metadata.abstractText: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jclepro.2019.05.196 0959-6526/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved. Mineral based metal working fluids used in machining, results in environmental pollution and occupational health hazards for the operators. Consequently it is necessary to evolve out machining techniques which are environment friendly. In the present work, techniques such as cryogenic cooling and cryogenic treatment have been compared with Al2O3 nanoparticles based MQL cooling method (nMQL) in turning of the nickel based Nimonic 90 alloy. The machining of nickel based alloy has been carried out using the AlTiN coated tungsten carbide inserts of different nose radii. The effects of these cutting environments have been studied by comparing the tool wear, cutting forces, work surface defects, surface finish, and chip underside surfaces. The application of liquid nitrogen as a cooling medium significantly reduced the tool flank wear of the 0.2mm nose radius insert by 38% as compared to nMQL technique. The SEM investigation of rake face revealed that the cryogenic cooling technique has also prevented the groove formation and peeling of the coating. The effective cushioning effect of liquid nitrogen as coolant improved the surface finish as compared to other techniques. The cryogenic cooling reduced the defects such as material side flow, material redeposition and micro cavities over the machined surface. Overall the cryogenic cooling environment has been found to be the best mode for the machining of the Nimonic 90 alloy. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
